The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.

Unit 2 â€“ Session 3: Describing Yourself and Supporting Others

Welcome to Session 3

Welcome to Session 3 of Unit 2: Building Your Professional Profile. In this session, youâ€™ll improve your ability to describe professional experiences and offer advice using accurate and expressive language â€” essential skills in any workplace.

Weâ€™ll focus on using -ED and -ING adjectives correctly, a key grammar point for describing feelings, situations, and personal qualities. Youâ€™ll also explore how to write clearly and professionally, using language that highlights your strengths and supports your colleagues.

You Will

  • Review the difference between -ED and -ING adjectives to describe emotions and situations accurately.
  • Practise grammar and vocabulary through interactive activities.
  • Write a short profile or piece of advice using professional tone and relevant workplace language.
  • Learn how to give and receive feedback in writing.

ðŸ’¡ Why Is This Important?

Whether youâ€™re talking about your experience in a job interview or writing a message to help a colleague, your ability to express how you feel and what causes that feeling matters. For example:

  • â†’ Iâ€™m motivated because the work is exciting.
  • â†’ She was confused by the instructions.

This session will help you become more precise and confident when describing people, situations, and your own abilities in English.

Get ready to express yourself clearly and support others professionally!

âœ¨ Ready to boost your communication skills and support others with your words? Letâ€™s get started!

ðŸ“˜ Use of English â€“ Unit 2, Session 21: -ED / -ING Adjectives

Introduction

In this section, you'll explore a key grammar topic: the difference between adjectives that end in -ED and those that end in -ING.

Understanding this difference will help you speak and write more accurately when describing feelings and situations â€” both in everyday conversations and in professional contexts.

ðŸ” Step 1: Diagnostic Test

Start by doing a short diagnostic test. This will help you check what you already know about -ED and -ING adjectives.

  • ðŸ§ª 30 fill-in-the-blank exercises
  • ðŸ“‹ Answer Key included at the end
  • ðŸŽ¯ Use the results to decide if you need more practice

ðŸ“– Step 2: Grammar Explanation

Now it's time to understand the rule. You'll learn when to use:

  • -ED adjectives â†’ to describe how someone feels
  • -ING adjectives â†’ to describe what causes the feeling

You'll also see examples and tips to avoid common mistakes.

ðŸ“ Step 3: Practice Activities

Test yourself with different types of practice activities:

  • âœ”ï¸ Multiple choice
  • âœ”ï¸ Fill-in-the-gap
  • âœ”ï¸ Matching exercises
  • âœ”ï¸ Sentence transformation
  • ðŸŽ§ Cloze activity with audio

All exercises are interactive and give you instant feedback.

ðŸ’¡ Tip

If youâ€™re unsure after the test, go back to the explanation before you complete the rest of the activities.

Master these adjectives to express yourself clearly in any professional setting!

âœ¨ Start now and enhance your English precision!

  • âœ… -ING adjectives â€“ what causes that feeling (e.g. boring, exciting)

This isnâ€™t a test for marks â€” itâ€™s a tool to help you understand your learning needs.

Competencies

ðŸ“‹ Diagnostic Test: -ED and -ING Adjectives (B1)

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This diagnostic test assesses your ability to use -ED and -ING adjectives correctly, a key skill for describing feelings and situations in professional and everyday contexts. -ING adjectives describe the cause of a feeling (e.g., an interesting story), while -ED adjectives describe the feeling itself (e.g., feeling interested). Use these strategies:

  • Identify the subject: If the subject feels the emotion (e.g., â€œI wasâ€¦â€), use -ED. If the subject causes the emotion (e.g., â€œThe story wasâ€¦â€), use -ING.
  • Use the verb clue: The verb in parentheses (e.g., â€œinterestâ€) guides the adjective form.
  • Check context: Consider whether the sentence describes a feeling or a quality.

Complete the 20 sentences below by typing the correct adjective (e.g., â€œinterestingâ€ or â€œinterestedâ€). Click "Check Answers" for instant feedback. Each correct answer is worth 1 point (20 points total). Aim for 16 or more (80%) to show proficiency. If you score less than 16, review the -ED vs. -ING rules.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Ask yourself: Is the subject feeling the emotion (-ED) or causing it (-ING)?

âœï¸ Exercise: Complete the Sentences (20 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct -ED or -ING adjective based on the verb in parentheses. Type the exact adjective (e.g., â€œinterestingâ€). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. The story was very ___ (interest).

  • 2. I was really ___ by his presentation (impress).

  • 3. That was the most ___ film Iâ€™ve ever seen (bore).

  • 4. He looked ___ after walking for hours (tire).

  • 5. We were ___ when we heard the good news (excite).

  • 6. The instructions were too ___ to understand (confuse).

  • 7. She felt ___ when nobody called her (disappoint).

  • 8. The results of the experiment were quite ___ (surprise).

  • 9. Are you ___ in learning another language? (interest)

  • 10. This heat is really ___ (exhaust).

  • 11. My parents were ___ by my decision (shock).

  • 12. That noise was so ___ that I couldnâ€™t sleep (annoy).

  • 13. I get ___ when people talk too loudly in public places (annoy).

  • 14. The students looked ___ during the lecture (bore).

  • 15. The documentary was truly ___ (fascinate).

  • 16. He was ___ to find out the truth (surprise).

  • 17. What an ___ story! (amaze)

  • 18. She was clearly ___ by the math problem (confuse).

  • 19. That book was the most ___ thing I read this year (inspire).

  • 20. They were ___ by the lack of communication (frustrate).

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use the verb in parentheses to form the correct adjective!

ðŸ“Š Your Score

Click "Check Answers" to see your score.

-ED and -ING Adjectives in English â€“ Unit 2, Session 3

Introduction

In English, many adjectives come from verbs and have two forms: one ending in -ED and one ending in -ING. These forms have different meanings, and understanding them will help you describe feelings and situations accurately.

ðŸŽ§ Complementary Audio â€“ Guided Explanation
This audio supports you as you go through the lesson. Listen to it for a step-by-step explanation with spoken examples. Itâ€™s especially helpful if you prefer learning by listening or want to review while doing other tasks.

Whatâ€™s the Difference?

-ED adjectives describe how someone feels.

-ING adjectives describe the person, thing, or situation that causes the feeling.

Example:

  • I am bored. (I feel bored.)
  • The movie is boring. (The movie causes boredom.)

-ED Adjectives: Describing Feelings

Use -ED adjectives to talk about emotions or how someone feels. They are often used with verbs like be (am, is, are, was, were), feel, or look.

Examples:

  • She is surprised. (She feels surprise.)
  • We were exhausted. (We felt very tired.)
  • He looks worried. (He seems to feel worry.)

-ING Adjectives: Describing the Cause

Use -ING adjectives to describe the thing, person, or situation that causes the emotion.

Examples:

  • The book is interesting. (The book causes interest.)
  • The news was shocking. (The news caused shock.)
  • This puzzle is confusing. (The puzzle causes confusion.)

Important: They Are NOT Interchangeable!

Using the wrong form can change the meaning of your sentence completely.

Sentence Meaning
I am interested. I feel interest.
I am interesting. I cause interest â€“ people think I am fascinating!
He is tired. He feels tired.
He is tiring. He makes others feel tired.

Watch out! Saying â€œI am boringâ€ means you think youâ€™re not interesting to others. If you want to say you feel bored, say â€œI am bored.â€

Common -ED and -ING Adjectives

Here are some common verbs that form -ED and -ING adjectives:

Verb -ED Adjective -ING Adjective
interest interested interesting
bore bored boring
surprise surprised surprising
confuse confused confusing
exhaust exhausted exhausting
frighten frightened frightening
disappoint disappointed disappointing

Quick Tips for Choosing the Right Adjective

If you can say â€œI feelâ€¦â€, use the -ED adjective:

  • I feel relaxed / tired / frustrated.

If you can say â€œIt isâ€¦â€, use the -ING adjective:

  • It is relaxing / tiring / frustrating.

Pro Tip

Practice by describing how you feel (-ED) and what causes it (-ING). For example: â€œI am excited because the party is exciting!â€

Use these adjectives to describe workplace experiences with clarity and confidence!

âœ¨ Master this grammar to shine in professional communication!

Practice Exercises: -ED and -ING AdjectivesÂ 

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This practice set helps you master -ED and -ING adjectives to describe feelings and situations, essential for expressing yourself in professional and everyday contexts. -ING adjectives describe what causes a feeling (e.g., a tiring meeting), while -ED adjectives describe the feeling itself (e.g., feeling tired). Use these strategies:

  • Check the subject: Use -ED if the subject feels the emotion (e.g., â€œI wasâ€¦â€), -ING if it causes the emotion (e.g., â€œThe meeting wasâ€¦â€).
  • Use context clues: Think about whether the sentence describes a feeling or a quality.
  • Rewrite carefully: For transformations, adjust the sentence structure to keep the meaning clear.

Complete the 31 items across five exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback. Each correct answer is worth 1 point (31 points total). Aim for 25 or more (~80%) to confirm proficiency. If you score less than 25, review the -ED vs. -ING rules.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Ask yourself: Is the subject feeling the emotion (-ED) or causing it (-ING)?

âœï¸ Exercise 1: Cloze Test (8 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct -ED or -ING adjective formed from the verb in parentheses. Type the exact adjective (e.g., â€œtiringâ€). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. The long meeting was so ___ (tire) that everyone wanted a break.

  • 2. Iâ€™m really ___ (excite) about my new English course!

  • 3. The instructions were very ___ (confuse), so I asked for help.

  • 4. She was ___ (frighten) when she heard a strange noise at night.

  • 5. This documentary is really ___ (interest); I learned a lot!

  • 6. He felt ___ (disappoint) when his team lost the game.

  • 7. The roller coaster was so ___ (thrill) that we rode it twice!

  • 8. We were ___ (bore) during the long wait at the airport.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use the verb in parentheses to form the correct adjective!

â“ Exercise 2: Multiple Choice Quiz (6 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct -ED or -ING adjective to complete each sentence. Select the option using the radio buttons. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 9. The horror movie was so ___ that I couldnâ€™t sleep!

  • 10. Iâ€™m really ___ about my vacation next week!

  • 11. The teacherâ€™s explanation was very ___.

  • 12. She was ___ when she saw the beautiful surprise party.

  • 13. This book is so ___; I canâ€™t stop reading it!

  • 14. He looked ___ after working all day without a break.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about whether the subject feels or causes the emotion!

ðŸ”„ Exercise 3: Sentence Transformation (6 items)

Instructions: Rewrite each sentence using the opposite form of the adjective (-ED or -ING). Make necessary changes to keep the meaning clear. Type the full sentence. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 15. The puzzle is confusing.


  • 16. Iâ€™m excited about the trip.


  • 17. The news was shocking.


  • 18. She felt disappointed with the results.


  • 19. The game is tiring.


  • 20. He was interested in the lecture.


ðŸ’¡ Tip: Adjust the subject and structure to match the new adjective!

ðŸ”— Exercise 4: Matching Exercise (5 items)

Instructions: Match each sentence with the correct -ED or -ING adjective by selecting the option from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

21. The haunted house was so scary!
22. I feel so tired after the long day.
23. This novel is really fun to read.
24. She was upset because her phone broke.
25. The loud music made me angry.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Match the adjective to the sentenceâ€™s context!

ðŸŽ™ï¸ Exercise 5: Cloze Text with Audio (6 items)

Instructions: Listen to the audio narration of a short story. Fill in the blanks with the correct -ED or -ING adjective based on what you hear and understand. Type the exact adjective (e.g., â€œthrillingâ€). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.



Last weekend, I went to an amusement park with my friends. The rides were so (thrill) that my heart was racing! I felt very (excite) when we tried the biggest roller coaster. However, the long lines were (bore), and I got really (bore) waiting. The fireworks show at night was (amaze), and we were all (amaze) by the colors. It was a great day!

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Listen for the context of each adjective in the story!

Unit 2 â€“ Writing: Showcasing Skills and Supporting Colleagues

Overview

This writing section empowers you to communicate professionally in workplace contexts. You will develop skills to:

  • Craft a compelling professional profile with precise language.
  • Highlight hard and soft skills confidently yet courteously.
  • Use grammatical structures to enhance professionalism.
  • Produce concise, workplace-relevant texts.

Through a guided sequence, youâ€™ll progress from planning to creating impactful written communication.

Section Structure

Follow these steps to build your writing proficiency:

  1. Writing Lesson: Mastering Professional Tone
    Learn to use boosters and hedges to strengthen or soften your message, improving how you present yourself and offer advice.
  2. Writing Practice: Highlighting Your Strengths
    Write a short message (80â€“100 words) describing your professional skills, share it in the forum, and provide feedback on a classmateâ€™s post.
  3. Final Writing Task: Advising a Colleague
    Compose an email responding to a colleague seeking advice on preparing for a job opportunity, applying unit grammar and vocabulary.

Why This Matters

Clear and professional writing is a cornerstone of workplace success. Whether crafting a job application, supporting a colleague, or articulating your expertise, mastering tone and structure will help you make a lasting impression in any professional setting.

Develop your writing skills to stand out and support others in the workplace!

âœ¨ Start crafting professional texts with confidence!

Writing Lesson: Crafting Professional and Precise Texts

Why This Matters

Effective professional writing conveys confidence, respect, and clarity. Whether describing your strengths or offering advice, the way you express ideas can significantly impact your message. This lesson focuses on:

  • Using boosters to project confidence.
  • Applying hedges for politeness and flexibility.
  • Avoiding overly direct or informal language to maintain professionalism.

1. Boosters: Conveying Confidence

Boosters are words or phrases that strengthen your statements, ideal for showcasing skills or making firm recommendations.

Examples:

  • âœ“ I am fully confident in leading complex projects.
  • âœ“ She is exceptionally skilled at problem-solving.
  • âœ“ It is absolutely critical to prioritize time management.

Useful Boosters:

absolutely, clearly, definitely, especially, in fact, without a doubt, strongly, truly

2. Hedges: Softening Tone for Politeness

Hedges help you offer suggestions or opinions without sounding overly assertive, making your writing more approachable and professional.

Examples:

  • âœ“ You might consider emphasizing your technical skills.
  • âœ“ It could be beneficial to include specific examples.
  • âœ“ This may provide an opportunity to demonstrate leadership.

Useful Hedges:

might, could, may, tend to, in general, often, it seems, perhaps, possibly, one option is

3. Avoiding Informal or Overly Direct Language

Certain phrases can undermine professionalism by sounding too casual or blunt. Replace them with polished alternatives.

Examples:

  • âŒ I think you should add more details. â†’ âœ“ You might consider including more details.
  • âŒ You need to be clear. â†’ âœ“ It is important to ensure clarity.
  • âŒ Just say youâ€™re good at coding. â†’ âœ“ You could highlight your proficiency in coding.

Practice: Elevate Your Writing

Start with a simple sentence and enhance it using boosters or hedges for a more professional tone.

Basic Sentence:

Communication is important.

Upgraded Examples:

  • âœ“ Without a doubt, communication is a cornerstone of workplace success.
  • âœ“ In general, effective communication can significantly enhance team collaboration.
  • âœ“ It might be advantageous to emphasize communication as a core strength.

Key Takeaway

Adapt your tone to your audience. To maintain professionalism:

  • Use boosters to assert confidence in your skills or recommendations.
  • Apply hedges to soften suggestions and maintain courtesy.
  • Opt for precise, formal vocabulary over vague or casual expressions.
Craft professional texts with confidence and make a lasting impression!

âœ¨ Elevate your writing to shine in workplace communication!

Unit 2 â€“ Writing Practice: Sharing Your Strengths

Task Description

Showcase your professional strengths in a concise message (80â€“100 words). Highlight the skills and qualities that make you an exceptional worker or student.

ðŸ’¬ Instructions

Write a short paragraph that includes:

  • A hard skill (e.g., proficiency in software, task management).
  • A soft skill (e.g., teamwork, adaptability).
  • An adjective ending in â€“ed or â€“ing (e.g., motivated, inspiring).
  • An impersonal structure (e.g., It is essential to stay organized).

Use clear, professional language as if presenting yourself to a potential employer or crafting a profile for a professional platform.

ðŸ’¡ Helpful Tips

Review Session 2 vocabulary (skills) and Sessions 1 & 3 grammar (impersonal structures, â€“ed/â€“ing adjectives).

Keep the tone friendly yet professionalâ€”no formal email structure needed.

Use this task to brainstorm ideas for your final writing assignment.

Share your strengths with confidence and connect with your classmates!

âœ¨ Craft a message that highlights your unique skills!

Unit 2 â€“ Speaking: Building Connections at Work

Overview

This speaking section focuses on enhancing your ability to communicate effectively in professional settings. You will develop skills to:

  • Articulate your professional values and workplace experiences.
  • Analyze and reflect on communication challenges.
  • Provide clear, respectful, and supportive advice.
  • Navigate cultural differences with empathy in diverse work environments.

Through a structured progression, youâ€™ll build confidence in real-world communication.

Section Structure

Follow these steps to master workplace communication:

  1. Speaking Lesson: Understanding Workplace Dynamics
    Learn to describe workplace scenarios, explain cultural or communication differences, and offer polite advice.
  2. Speaking Practice: A Workplace Misunderstanding
    Record a 1â€“2 minute audio or video narrating a workplace misunderstanding and its resolution.
  3. Final Speaking Task: Supporting a New Colleague
    Act as a mentor, recording advice to help a new colleague from Poland adapt to the Spanish workplace.

Why This Matters

In todayâ€™s global workplaces, strong communication and cultural sensitivity are vital. These activities equip you with practical phrases and strategies for multicultural settings, empowering you to speak confidently and connect meaningfully in professional contexts.

Build connections with confidence and empathy in diverse workplaces!

âœ¨ Start speaking to create meaningful professional relationships!

Speaking Lesson: Fostering Understanding in the Workplace

Lesson Objectives

This lesson equips you with skills to navigate workplace interactions effectively. You will learn to:

  • Discuss workplace challenges with clarity.
  • Analyze misunderstandings, including cultural influences.
  • Offer polite, constructive advice to newcomers.
  • Structure your speech for fluency and empathy.

These skills prepare you for:

  • Practice Task: Narrating a Workplace Misunderstanding
  • Final Task: Advising a New Colleague from Poland

1. Understanding Workplace Misunderstandings

Misunderstandings often arise from:

  • Differing expectations (e.g., approaches to deadlines or collaboration).
  • Missing context (e.g., a comment seems abrupt without background).
  • Cultural norms (e.g., directness in feedback or formality levels).

Practice Describing:

  • â€œI initially thought my colleague was dismissive, but I realized their direct style was cultural.â€
  • â€œWe disagreed on meeting times because our views on punctuality differed.â€

2. Key Phrases for Narration and Reflection

To Describe a Situation:

  • A situation occurred whereâ€¦
  • I worked with someone whoâ€¦
  • During a project, I noticedâ€¦

To Explain the Cause:

  • The issue stemmed fromâ€¦
  • We had a misunderstanding due toâ€¦
  • It was unfamiliar to me becauseâ€¦

To Reflect or Show Empathy:

  • I now understand thatâ€¦
  • This experience taught me toâ€¦
  • Being adaptable is essential becauseâ€¦

3. Offering Polite Advice

When advising a newcomer, use a warm, encouraging tone to avoid sounding authoritative.

Effective Phrases:

  • â€œYou might find it helpful toâ€¦â€
  • â€œItâ€™s useful to know thatâ€¦â€
  • â€œIf youâ€™re unsure, feel free toâ€¦â€
  • â€œItâ€™s common here toâ€¦ so donâ€™t be surprised ifâ€¦â€

Example:

â€œThings might seem fast-paced at first, but asking questions is always welcomed.â€

4. Structuring Your Speech

Use this clear framework for both tasks:

  • Introduce: Set the scene briefly.
  • Explain: Describe the issue or cultural difference.
  • Reflect or Advise: Share lessons or suggestions.
  • Conclude: End with an optimistic note.

This structure keeps your thoughts organized and engaging.

Ready to Begin?

Proceed to the tasks with confidence:

  • Practice Task: Share a story about a workplace misunderstanding.
  • Final Task: Offer guidance to a new colleague from Poland.

Speak naturally, focusing on clarity and kindness. Perfection isnâ€™t the goalâ€”connection is.

Build meaningful connections through clear and empathetic communication!

âœ¨ Speak with confidence to foster understanding at work!

Unit 2 â€“ Speaking Practice: Resolving a Workplace Misunderstanding

Task Description

Recall or invent a workplace misunderstanding from a job, internship, or project. Record a short audio or video (1â€“2 minutes) narrating the experience and reflecting on its lessons.

Submit your recording to the Unit 2 â€“ Speaking Practice Forum for classmates and your teacher to review.

Instructions

Your spoken story should include:

  • A description of the situation: What occurred, and who was involved?
  • The cause of the misunderstanding (e.g., communication issues, cultural differences, or assumptions).
  • How the issue was resolved or a suggestion for how it could have been resolved.
  • A brief reflection: What lesson can be learned from this experience?

Keep your delivery clear and natural, using notes if needed but avoiding reading directly.

Where to Submit

Upload your 1â€“2 minute audio or video to the Unit 2 â€“ Speaking Practice Forum: Workplace Experiences.

Listen to at least one classmateâ€™s recording and provide a brief, constructive comment.

Helpful Phrases

â€œInitially, there was confusion becauseâ€¦â€

â€œIn my experience, perhaps due toâ€¦â€

â€œA possible solution could have beenâ€¦â€

â€œThis experience showed me thatâ€¦â€

â€œI now understand the value ofâ€¦â€

Share your story with clarity and connect with your classmates!

âœ¨ Narrate your experience to build stronger workplace communication!

ðŸŽ‰ Unit 2 Complete: Celebrate Your Growth! ðŸŽ‰

Reflect on Your Journey in Building Your Professional Profile

ðŸŽ‰ Congratulations! You've successfully completed Unit 2! ðŸŽ‰

Your Achievements

In this unit, you've developed essential skills for professional communication:

  • Described your hard and soft skills with confidence.
  • Used â€“ED and â€“ING adjectives to express feelings and describe situations.
  • Offered professional advice using polite and clear language.
  • Communicated with empathy in diverse, multicultural workplace scenarios.
  • Shared insights about real workplace experiences through writing and speaking.

Why Reflection Matters

Taking time to reflect helps you:

  • Recognize your progress and build confidence.
  • Strengthen your Competence to Learn to Learn.
  • Support your Competence for Lifelong Learning.
  • Prepare to use English effectively in professional and real-life settings.

Be honest, celebrate your growth, and identify areas for further improvement!

Personal Self-Assessment

Pause and reflect on your journey. Write down your thoughts to solidify your learning.

Language & Communication

  • Can you confidently describe your professional strengths and values?
  • Are you able to give polite and constructive advice to a colleague?
  • Can you discuss workplace misunderstandings or cultural differences effectively?

Grammar & Vocabulary

  • Do you feel comfortable using â€“ED and â€“ING adjectives?
  • Are you using impersonal structures accurately (e.g., "It is essential toâ€¦")?
  • Have you incorporated professional vocabulary relevant to your field?

Learning Process

  • Did the Planning Sheets help you structure your writing and speaking tasks?
  • Did you apply lessons from the Writing and Speaking sections to your final tasks?
  • Did you actively participate by posting and engaging in the forum?

Looking Ahead

  • What was the most valuable skill or lesson you gained from this unit?
  • What areas would you like to focus on improving in the next unit?
  • How can you take ownership of your learning moving forward?
Celebrate your achievements and plan your next steps with confidence!

âœ¨ Reflect on your growth and get ready for new challenges!
